title: Theresa May orders ministers to STOP STURGEON demanding independence referendum
text:
Theresa May orders ministers to STOP STURGEON demanding independence referendum Theresa May orders ministers to STOP STURGEON demanding independence referendum THERESA May has ordered every minister in her Cabinet to play their part in preventing Nicola Sturgeon from breaking up Britain. PUBLISHED: 17:30,  35, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 
In a major cross-departmental government campaign the Prime Minister today told colleagues to help the Union "work and stay together". 
It comes amid speculation Ms Sturgeon is just "weeks away" from demanding another independence referendum. 
The SNP's spring conference is in Aberdeen next month and activists hope the First Minister may reveal her plans then. Related articles GETTY Theresa May told colleagues to help the Union 'work and stay together' 
Ms Sturgeon has warned a second poll is "looming" after demanding a bespoke Brexit deal that would allow Scotland to stay in the EU's single market. The Prime Minister said the government recognised how much we all value the Union, how it had been an incredibly successful partnership Number 10 spokesman 
The issue of "sustaining the Union" was discussed alongside Russia and took up almost all the weekly Cabinet meeting. 
Downing Street said talks "touched on" the threat of a second referendum but restated the UK Government's position "there shouldn't" be one. 
A Number 10 spokesman said: "The Prime Minister said the government recognised how much we all value the Union, how it had been an incredibly successful partnership. GETTY Sturgeon has warned a second poll is 'looming' after demanding a bespoke Brexit deal What Theresa May's 12-point Brexit plan really means Mon, January 16, 2017 1 of 7 Continued cooperation with the EU to tackle terrorism and international crime. 
"We must continue to point that out. She added that everyone around the table wants the Union to work and stay together." 
Cabinet Office minister Ben Gummer stressed all departments should "continue to listen to and engage with the devolved administrations", the spokesman added. 
"He pointed out that it is the most successful political union ever seen, and it is critical that we continue to maintain, strengthen and nurture the 300 plus year-old relationship." 
Individual Cabinet secretaries then talked about work of their departments and the "importance of maintaining a level of engagement to strengthen and enhance the Union going forward." 
The Scottish Government has also called for new powers over immigration to be devolved to Holyrood as part of its demands for a differentiated EU deal. 
But UK ministers and experts have said the Norway-style package is unlikely due to its complexity. GETTY Scottish Secretary David Mundell will appear before MSPs at Holyrood tomorrow 
Scottish Secretary David Mundell will appear before MSPs at Holyrood tomorrow, where he will say Scotland will leave the EU along with the rest of the UK. 
At the weekend it emerged pro-independence group Business for Scotland has a fund-raising drive to get "back in full campaign mode" with claims another referendum could be held next autumn. 
But the power to hold one remains reserved to the UK Government. Holding one requires Westminster to grant a Section 30 Order. 
Whitehall sources later stressed Mrs May has repeatedly shown her determination to strengthen the Union, highlighting the UK Government's White Paper on Brexit committed to handing more powers to Holyrood. 
But an SNP spokesman said: "This shows the Tories are clearly rattled at how their actions are being seen by people across Scotland - and they have good reason to be. 
"They talk about listening seriously to Scotland but their actions tell a completely different story - underlined by the fact the UK Cabinet failed to discuss the Scottish Government's compromise proposals on Europe." Related articles
